","field":6,"settings":[]}]},"settings":[],"parent":78}],"fieldId":"contentblocks-field-125"}},{"heading":{"value":"Specifications","fieldId":"contentblocks-field-127"},"content":{"child_layouts":[{"layout":7,"content":{"main":[{"chunk_selector":"patternLibraryLabels","chunk_selector_properties":{"__other__":"&electron_type=`Template Variable`"},"field":85,"settings":[]},{"value":"{ "caption": "Layout type", "name": "fb_form_layout", "description": "Stacked means the labels are always above the input fields, Horizontal means the labels are next to the fields, Inline means everything is on 1 row (so only for very small forms).", "category": "Settings - General", "sortOrder": "5", "type": "listbox", "inputOptionValues": "Stacked==vertical||Horizontal==horizontal||Inline==inline", "defaultValue": "horizontal", "templates": ["fbForm"] }","lang":"json","field":83,"settings":[]}]},"settings":[],"parent":78}],"fieldId":"contentblocks-field-128"}},{"heading":{"value":"References","fieldId":"contentblocks-field-131"},"content":{"child_layouts":[{"layout":12,"content":{"col_1":[{"value":"Assigned to the following templates","level":"h5","field":1,"settings":[]},{"chunk_selector":"assignedTemplates","chunk_selector_properties":{},"field":84,"settings":{"pattern_name":"fb_form_layout"}}],"col_2":[{"value":"Included in the following patterns","level":"h5","field":1,"settings":[]},{"chunk_selector":"referringTemplates","chunk_selector_properties":{},"field":84,"settings":{"pattern_name":"fb_form_layout"}}]},"settings":{"padding":"relaxed","alignment":"","divider":"divided"},"parent":78}],"fieldId":"contentblocks-field-132"}}],"field":76,"settings":{"layout_type":"accordion","accordion_type":"fluid styled","padding":"padded"}}]},"settings":[],"parent":0,"title":"fb_form_layout"},{"layout":1,"content":{"main":[{"value":"fb_email_to_dynamic","level":"h2","field":1,"settings":{"alignment":"","anchor":"Anchor"}},{"rows":[{"heading":{"value":"Purpose","fieldId":"contentblocks-field-139"},"content":{"child_layouts":[{"layout":7,"content":{"main":[{"value":"

With this TV you can override the default fb_email_to field by a dynamically generated email address. This can be done by placing a custom snippet call inside the textarea of this TV. You can use any snippet you like, as long as it returns a valid email address (or comma separated list of addresses).

","field":6,"settings":[]}]},"settings":[],"parent":78}],"fieldId":"contentblocks-field-140"}},{"heading":{"value":"Usage","fieldId":"contentblocks-field-142"},"content":{"child_layouts":[{"layout":7,"content":{"main":[{"value":"

As an example, consider the following scenario:

You're building a website for an organization with several departments. Each department wants to have its own page on the site, with the option to contact that department directly through a web form. The form can be the same for all departments, but they want to have it sent to a different person in each case.

At this point you might think: let's just create a TV and attach it to template that all departments pages use. Then simply retrieve the value of this TV inside the fb_email_to field, instead of entering a real email address there. Unfortunately this won't work, because:

  • The fb_email_to field is expecting an email address, meaning a string containing an @
  • The form is coming from a different resource, meaning its content is already rendered when being loaded on the page

This is where the fb_email_to_dynamic field comes in. We can fetch the TV containing the email address of the department by sending out a snippet to go look for it. As you can see under Specifications, we can use the current_id placeholder to look inside the resource containing the form. The snippet call could be something like this (using the fastField shorthand syntax of pdoParser):

","field":6,"settings":[]},{"value":"[[#[[+current_id]].tv.department_email]]","lang":"html","field":13,"settings":[]},{"value":"

Now the same form can be used on multiple different pages, with a unique email_to address for every page.

","field":6,"settings":[]}]},"settings":[],"parent":78}],"fieldId":"contentblocks-field-143"}},{"heading":{"value":"Specifications","fieldId":"contentblocks-field-147"},"content":{"child_layouts":[{"layout":7,"content":{"main":[{"chunk_selector":"patternLibraryLabels","chunk_selector_properties":{"__other__":"&electron_type=`Template Variable`"},"field":85,"settings":[]},{"value":"{ "caption": "Dynamic recipient address", "name": "fb_email_to_dynamic", "description": "You can place any snippet / FastField call here that outputs a single email address. Retrieve something inside a resource by using the [[+current_id]] placeholder. WARNING: populating this field will override the default recipient address, so test thoroughly!", "category": "Settings - Advanced", "sortOrder": "1", "type": "textarea", "templates": ["fbForm"] }","lang":"json","field":83,"settings":[]}]},"settings":[],"parent":78}],"fieldId":"contentblocks-field-148"}},{"heading":{"value":"References","fieldId":"contentblocks-field-151"},"content":{"child_layouts":[{"layout":12,"content":{"col_1":[{"value":"Assigned to the following templates","level":"h5","field":1,"settings":[]},{"chunk_selector":"assignedTemplates","chunk_selector_properties":{},"field":84,"settings":{"pattern_name":"fb_email_to_dynamic"}}],"col_2":[{"value":"Included in the following patterns","level":"h5","field":1,"settings":[]},{"chunk_selector":"referringTemplates","chunk_selector_properties":{},"field":84,"settings":{"pattern_name":"fb_email_to_dynamic"}}]},"settings":{"padding":"relaxed","alignment":"","divider":"divided"},"parent":78}],"fieldId":"contentblocks-field-152"}}],"field":76,"settings":{"layout_type":"accordion","accordion_type":"fluid styled","padding":"padded"}}]},"settings":[],"parent":0,"title":"fb_email_to_dynamic"},{"layout":1,"content":{"main":[{"value":"fb_email_template","level":"h2","field":1,"settings":{"alignment":"","anchor":"Anchor"}},{"rows":[{"heading":{"value":"Purpose","fieldId":"contentblocks-field-159"},"content":{"child_layouts":[{"layout":7,"content":{"main":[{"value":"

It will appear as if the autoresponder was sent from this email address.

Control to which email address a direct response from the form submitter will be sent. In other words: if the form submitter uses the "reply" button in his or her email client, that message will go to this email address.

This is for cases where you might want to use a different address than the one in fb_autoresponder_from. For example: use website@example.com as from address, but receive replies on support@example.com.

main.value: Define an email address where forms will be sent to.

{
    "caption": "Email address recipient",
    "name": "fb_email_to",
    "description": "Submitted forms will be sent to this address. If this field is empty, the form will be sent to the default email address of the website (which can be found under Extras > Configuration).",
    "category": "Settings - Email",
    "sortOrder": "1",
    "type": "email",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Define a CC address where forms will also be sent to.

{
    "caption": "Email CC address",
    "name": "fb_email_cc",
    "description": "Optional.",
    "category": "Settings - Email",
    "sortOrder": "2",
    "type": "email",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}

Define a BCC address where forms will also be sent to.

Tip: this can be convenient for linking your form to an automated service like Zapier.

{
    "caption": "Email BCC address",
    "name": "fb_email_bcc",
    "description": "Optional.",
    "category": "Settings - Email",
    "sortOrder": "3",
    "type": "email",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
It will appear as if the form was sent from this email address.

{
    "caption": "Email FROM address",
    "name": "fb_email_from",
    "description": "Optional. Defaults to emailsender system setting.",
    "category": "Settings - Email",
    "sortOrder": "5",
    "type": "email",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
It will appear as if the form was sent by this person or organization.

{
    "caption": "Email FROM name",
    "name": "fb_email_from_name",
    "description": "Optional. Defaults to site_name system setting.",
    "category": "Settings - Email",
    "sortOrder": "6",
    "type": "text",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Provides the subject line for an email message.

{
    "caption": "Email subject",
    "name": "fb_email_subject",
    "category": "Settings - Email",
    "sortOrder": "10",
    "type": "text",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Allows you to link to a specific redirect page.

{
    "caption": "Redirect page",
    "name": "fb_redirect_id",
    "description": "Enter the ID of the page, or drag the page from the menu tree to this input field.",
    "category": "Settings - General",
    "sortOrder": "90",
    "type": "number",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Allows you to change the default text inside the submit button of each form.

{
    "caption": "Text in submit button",
    "name": "fb_submit_button",
    "description": "Defaults to Send.",
    "category": "Settings - General",
    "sortOrder": "92",
    "type": "text",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Allows you to change the appearance of a form by selecting the position of the labels.

{
    "caption": "Layout type",
    "name": "fb_form_layout",
    "description": "Stacked means the labels are always above the input fields, Horizontal means the labels are next to the fields, Inline means everything is on 1 row (so only for very small forms).",
    "category": "Settings - General",
    "sortOrder": "5",
    "type": "listbox",
    "inputOptionValues": "Stacked==vertical||Horizontal==horizontal||Inline==inline",
    "defaultValue": "horizontal",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}

With this TV you can override the default fb_email_to field by a dynamically generated email address. This can be done by placing a custom snippet call inside the textarea of this TV. You can use any snippet you like, as long as it returns a valid email address (or comma separated list of addresses).

As an example, consider the following scenario:

You're building a website for an organization with several departments. Each department wants to have its own page on the site, with the option to contact that department directly through a web form. The form can be the same for all departments, but they want to have it sent to a different person in each case.

At this point you might think: let's just create a TV and attach it to template that all departments pages use. Then simply retrieve the value of this TV inside the fb_email_to field, instead of entering a real email address there. Unfortunately this won't work, because:

  • The fb_email_to field is expecting an email address, meaning a string containing an @
  • The form is coming from a different resource, meaning its content is already rendered when being loaded on the page

This is where the fb_email_to_dynamic field comes in. We can fetch the TV containing the email address of the department by sending out a snippet to go look for it. As you can see under Specifications, we can use the current_id placeholder to look inside the resource containing the form. The snippet call could be something like this (using the fastField shorthand syntax of pdoParser):
[[#[[+current_id]].tv.department_email]]
Now the same form can be used on multiple different pages, with a unique email_to address for every page.

{
    "caption": "Dynamic recipient address",
    "name": "fb_email_to_dynamic",
    "description": "You can place any snippet / FastField call here that outputs a single email address. Retrieve something inside a resource by using the [[+current_id]] placeholder. WARNING: populating this field will override the default recipient address, so test thoroughly!",
    "category": "Settings - Advanced",
    "sortOrder": "1",
    "type": "textarea",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Enables you to use your own email template.

{
    "caption": "Email template",
    "name": "fb_email_template",
    "description": "Optional. Name of the chunk containing your own customized (HTML) email template. Make sure there is a [[+content]] placeholder in there for listing the fields.",
    "category": "Settings - Advanced",
    "sortOrder": "20",
    "type": "text",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Define rows for your custom email template.

{
    "caption": "Email template rows",
    "name": "fb_email_template_rows",
    "description": "Optional. Name of the chunk containing the customized HTML for the template rows. This will be used to display each individual field in your email. Use [[+label]] and [[+value]] placeholders to show the content.",
    "category": "Settings - Advanced",
    "sortOrder": "21",
    "type": "text",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Allows you to enable an automatic response message being sent to the person who submitted the form.

{
    "caption": "Autoresponder",
    "name": "fb_autoresponder_toggle",
    "description": "IMPORTANT! For the autoresponder to know which email address to use, the Input (Email) field needs to be present in the form.",
    "category": "Autoresponder",
    "sortOrder": "1",
    "type": "option",
    "inputOptionValues": "On==1||Off==0",
    "defaultValue": "0",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
It will appear as if the autoresponder was sent from this email address.

{
    "caption": "Autoresponder FROM address",
    "name": "fb_autoresponder_from",
    "description": "Optional. This is the address where the messages appear to be sent from. Can be a non-existing address, like noreply@yourdomain.com. Defaults to emailsender system setting.",
    "category": "Autoresponder",
    "sortOrder": "2",
    "type": "email",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
It will appear as if the autoresponder was sent by this person or organization.

{
    "caption": "Autoresponder FROM name",
    "name": "fb_autoresponder_from_name",
    "description": "Optional. This is the name that will (probably) be visible in the recipients' inbox. Defaults to site_name system setting.",
    "category": "Autoresponder",
    "sortOrder": "3",
    "type": "text",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}

Control to which email address a direct response from the form submitter will be sent. In other words: if the form submitter uses the "reply" button in his or her email client, that message will go to this email address.

This is for cases where you might want to use a different address than the one in fb_autoresponder_from. For example: use website@example.com as from address, but receive replies on support@example.com.

{
    "caption": "Autoresponder REPLY TO address",
    "name": "fb_autoresponder_reply_to",
    "description": "Optional. This address will be used when recipient replies to this message directly. Defaults to respectively the client_email and emailsender system setting.",
    "category": "Autoresponder",
    "sortOrder": "4",
    "type": "email",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Provide a subject line for your autoresponse message.

{
    "caption": "Autoresponse subject",
    "name": "fb_autoresponder_subject",
    "description": "",
    "category": "Autoresponder",
    "sortOrder": "10",
    "type": "text",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Lets you write the autoresponse message in a text editor. You can personalize the message with placeholders from the form fields.

{
    "caption": "Autoresponse message",
    "name": "fb_autoresponder_message",
    "description": "The content of the email that will be sent. You can use placeholders here from the form fields you used. Just use the syntax [[+fb123-field-name]], so complete with prefix and correct name of the input field.",
    "category": "Autoresponder",
    "sortOrder": "11",
    "type": "richtext",
    "templates": ["fbForm"]
}
Specify which resource contains all the forms built with FormBlocks.
Enable or disable the option to save each form submission in the database. The saved forms can be accessed from the top menu through Extras > FormIt.

{
    "key": "save_form",
    "namespace": "formblocks",
    "type": "combo-boolean",
    "area": "FormBlocks - Settings",
    "value": "1"
}
Various settings for remembering the ID of the ContentBlocks fields containing the form inputs. So these are not their chunk IDs!
